A 7‑year‑old boy presented with progressive ataxia and cranial nerve VI palsy. MRI revealed a diffusely infiltrating pontine lesion measuring 2.5 cm in greatest dimension. A stereotactic biopsy confirmed diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) with the canonical H3‑K27M mutation and a concurrent ACVR1 G328V mutation. Baseline work‑up showed no metastatic disease. He received focal conformal radiation therapy to a total dose of 54 Gy in 30 fractions over six weeks, completing treatment without acute toxicity. Two weeks after radiation, he was enrolled in the Phase II ONC201‑DIPG trial (NCT03034200) and started oral ONC201 at 625 mg/m² daily (approx. 687 mg per dose based on his body surface area of 1.10 m²). After three cycles, MRI demonstrated a 35 % reduction in tumor volume, meeting criteria for a partial response. He tolerated ONC201 well, with only grade 1 nausea.

Six months after initiating ONC201, surveillance MRI showed new areas of contrast enhancement at the dorsal pons and a modest increase in tumor volume (approximately 10 % growth from nadir). Given radiographic progression, the treating team considered adding an HDAC inhibitor based on early data from the pediatric DIPG Combination Trial (NCT04567890). In that trial, patients received panobinostat at a dose of 20 mg/m² administered intravenously once weekly, in combination with continued ONC201 at the same dose. The combination cohort (n = 45) demonstrated a median overall survival (OS) of 18 months, compared with historical controls receiving radiation alone, whose median OS is 12 months. The reported median progression‑free survival (PFS) was 7 months versus 4 months in historical controls. The most common adverse events were grade 2 thrombocytopenia (15 %) and grade 1 fatigue (30 %). The trial protocol specifies that panobinostat dosing may be reduced to 15 mg/m² for patients experiencing grade 3 or higher toxicity, but no dose reduction is required at baseline.

The patient’s current weight is 30 kg, height 130 cm, yielding a calculated BSA of 1.10 m². Laboratory studies are within normal limits, and his platelet count is 250 × 10⁹/L. The family wishes to pursue the combination therapy to maximize survival benefit.

A 7‑year‑old boy presented with a 3‑month history of progressive gait instability and diplopia. MRI of the brain revealed a diffuse intrinsic pontine lesion measuring 3.2 cm in maximal diameter with characteristic T2 hyperintensity and minimal contrast enhancement. A stereotactic biopsy demonstrated a diffuse midline glioma, H3‑K27M‑mutant, WHO grade IV. Molecular profiling identified the following alterations: H3F3A K27M mutation, ACVR1 G328V activating mutation, and a germline TP53 pathogenic variant (c.818G>A, p.R273H). 

He was enrolled in a phase II clinical trial (NCT04214097) evaluating oral ONC201 administered at 125 mg/m² once weekly in combination with standard focal radiotherapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions) and concurrent temozolomide (75 mg/m² daily). Baseline MRI prior to therapy showed the 3.2 cm lesion. At the end of radiotherapy (week 6), MRI demonstrated a 20 % reduction in tumor volume without new areas of enhancement. Clinical status improved (Karnofsky Performance Score 80). 

At week 12 (approximately 6 weeks after completing radiotherapy), the patient experienced worsening cranial nerve deficits. Repeat MRI revealed progression: increase in tumor volume to 4.0 cm and new focal contrast enhancement suggestive of treatment‑refractory disease. The trial’s published interim analysis reported a median overall survival of 14 months and a 6‑month progression‑free survival of 55 % for participants receiving ONC201 with radiotherapy. 

Given the progression after ONC201‑based therapy, the treating team reviewed available salvage options. Literature on H3‑K27M‑mutant diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) indicates frequent activation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, particularly in tumors harboring ACVR1 mutations. Ongoing early‑phase studies are evaluating the brain‑penetrant PI3K/mTOR inhibitor paxalisib (GDC‑0084) at a dose of 70 mg orally twice daily combined with re‑irradiation (54 Gy in 30 fractions). Additionally, a separate phase I trial is assessing the oral PARP inhibitor olaparib (150 mg twice daily) in patients with germline TP53 mutations, based on synthetic lethality concepts. No further ONC201 trials are enrolling for post‑progression patients.

The family wishes to pursue the most evidence‑based, mutation‑directed salvage therapy available within a clinical trial setting.

A 7‑year‑old boy presented with a 3‑month history of gait instability and diplopia. MRI of the brain revealed a diffusely infiltrating pontine lesion measuring 3.2 cm in maximal diameter, consistent with diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG). An image‑guided stereotactic biopsy was performed, and molecular profiling demonstrated the following alterations: H3K27M mutation in the HIST1H3B gene, a missense ACVR1 G328V mutation, loss‑of‑function TP53 mutation, and an unmethylated MGMT promoter. 

Initial therapy consisted of focal conformal radiotherapy to a total dose of 54 Gy delivered in 30 fractions over 6 weeks, concurrent with temozolomide 75 mg/m² daily. After completion of radiotherapy, adjuvant temozolomide was given at 200 mg/m² on days 1‑5 of each 28‑day cycle for two cycles, but MRI at month 4 demonstrated radiographic progression. 

The patient was subsequently enrolled in a phase II clinical trial (NCT04567890) evaluating the combination of ONC201 (a selective dopamine‑receptor‑D2 antagonist) and the histone‑deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat. The trial protocol specifies ONC201 125 mg orally once weekly and panobinostat 20 mg/m² administered orally twice weekly (e.g., Monday and Thursday). After two 28‑day cycles, repeat MRI showed a 30 % reduction in tumor volume, meeting the criteria for a partial response. However, the patient developed grade 3 thrombocytopenia (platelet count 45 × 10⁹/L) attributed to panobinostat. According to the trial safety guidelines, for grade 3 hematologic toxicity the panobinostat dose should be reduced by 25 % while maintaining the ONC201 dose unchanged. The protocol further states that the reduced panobinostat dose should be rounded to the nearest whole milligram per square meter. 

The trial’s interim analysis reported an overall response rate of 35 % and a median progression‑free survival of 5.8 months. The most common grade 3‑4 adverse events were hematologic (thrombocytopenia, neutropenia) and were managed by dose modifications as described.

A 7‑year‑old boy presented with a 3‑cm pontine lesion consistent with diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG). Genetic profiling of the tumor revealed an H3K27M‑mutant histone and a concurrent ACVR1 G328V activating mutation. He was enrolled in a multicenter phase II trial (NCT03065200) evaluating the histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat combined with standard focal radiotherapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions). Panobinostat was administered intravenously at 10 mg/m² twice weekly during radiotherapy and continued as maintenance for up to 12 months. Additionally, the trial protocol mandated concurrent oral ONC201 at 625 mg once daily, beginning on day 1 of radiotherapy.

At the 8‑week MRI re‑assessment, the lesion size had decreased by 30 % (partial response) with no new neurological deficits. Toxicities included grade 2 thrombocytopenia (platelets 80 × 10⁹/L) and transient grade 1 nausea, both managed conservatively. By week 12, MRI showed stable disease; however, at week 20 the lesion enlarged by 15 % compared with baseline, and the patient developed new cranial nerve VI palsy.

The trial reported an overall median progression‑free survival (PFS) of 5.2 months (95 % CI 4.1–6.3) and a median overall survival (OS) of 12.8 months (95 % CI 10.9–14.7) for the whole cohort. Sub‑analysis indicated that patients harboring an ACVR1 mutation had a median PFS of 4.1 months, not significantly different from wild‑type patients.

Given progression after the combined panobinostat/ONC201 regimen, the treating team considered next‑line options: (1) enrollment in an investigational ACVR1‑selective inhibitor trial (e.g., momelotinib 200 mg orally once daily) which targets the activating ACVR1 mutation; (2) re‑irradiation (24 Gy in 12 fractions) followed by conventional chemotherapy with temozolomide 150 mg/m²/day for 5 days every 28 days; (3) off‑label use of the PD‑1 inhibitor nivolumab 3 mg/kg every 2 weeks; or (4) best supportive care. The family expressed a preference for a therapy that directly addresses the known ACVR1 mutation and has a manageable toxicity profile.
